reviews.review_msg: She seems like she really wants to be there. Its like she actually likes doing this!(?) Hard things get easier and I appreciate her patience. Raegan is also way hot.

Neil Madu is an interesting character to say the least. Crim 369 and 462 were not easy A's - there was no guidelines to grading the journal entries and there was no clear formula on how to succeed. Crim 462 was bigger waste of time - I was paired with someone that didn't even want me to be there for the field study. Madu offered no support.

Though the paper instructions may be vague, Neil is very open to meeting with students. If students take the initiative to try to receive a good mark, they will. He is very approachable and friendly and does not mind meeting one on one to discuss any assignment.

Weekly 3-page journals (50%), one partner project (20%), one individual project (20%), and weekly discussions (10%). The course is VERY disorganized. Instructions are unclear. Materially is fluffy. Don't take it unless you need it for 462. Overall though, compared to what my friends went through taking 369 on campus, I'd recommend taking it online

This class is decent, but there is a lot of writing. No midterm or exam though, and no research papers. The papers are just journals about your thoughts on the readings, so they're not too hard to write if you pay attention.

This course really is easy. It's just a LOT of writing. However, based on other comments I think it really depends on who your TA is if you want to do well in this course. Neil does 0 marking and lectures are absolutely useless. But HUGE GPA booster.

Horrible. His assignments are vague with totally random marking. His lectures are 2-hour-long sermons about zen and "authenticity" with maybe 1 tidbit of something related to criminology per class. He gets annoyed when you ask him questions about assignments, even due dates. His syllabus is incomprehensible, and he doesn't stick to it. HORRIBLE.

Ok, this class is not easy! I don't get where this lie comes from but this class is a lot of work! 10 journals + endless unit questions, group presentation, and interview critique in which you have to video tape yourself. If I have to breathe in class one more time and think that the world is full of sunshine, lollipops, and rainbows, i'll snap!!!

Possibly the easiest class I've taken at university. Marking may be arbitrary, but just have to spew their rhetoric back at them and you'll get an easy A. Madu himself is a poor professor. Disrespectful, unorganized, slow at marking, unprofessional, and in my experience, downright incompetent... how is this guy teaching at SFU?

A vapid, somnolent dog's breakfast of a course. And not a GPA booster necessarily -- marking is arbitrary, to put it kindly. Take this course only if you must -- i.e. if you're going to do a field practice

This class is ridiculous. Prof lectures too much about spirituality, completely muddling it up with course material. Journal entries should reflect his spiritual nature, making it difficult/ frustrating if you do not subsribe to his way of living. Journal entry instructions confusing as well.  Little less Zen, please, more on skills needed for crim

I took this course online and its only saving grace is that it is 4 credits. LOTS of writing, my days off from work were spending doing stupid journal entries talking about my feelings...made me so mad! LoL. TA was really patronizing, and told us that if we did not open our minds, we should expect to get a poor grade. Don't recommend.

- Good class. But u don't need to read all the books!! Definitely not a GPA booster! need to do the readings for the journals!! Just pick any one of the readings and talk about it in the journal! Don't need to read all the weekly readings!! No final or midterm exams!! Lectures are a bit dry  and boring at times! Interview critique was useless
crim 369= SFU's offical cake course.....if you can close your eyes and breathe then Neil will give you an A
A GPA booster (4 credits) but a complete waste of money and time. Neil pushes yoga and Buddhism way too much, and teaches general things that anyone with decency and ethics should know.

took it distance ed. there is A LOT of writing. 2 journal packages and an interview critique. overall i easily wrote over 200 pages for this course. it's not hard, but it is just very time consuming. can't say much about the prof though. he seemed very encouraging through first-class discussions.

The only word to describe the man is 'bureaucrat.' He talks around himself and thinks it's witty. The readings are of no help, for the most part they completely misrepresent zen/buddhist theory. If you read the Dalai Lama text, there is actual sense in the ideas Neil has obliterated through misconstruction.

Extremely nice guy, but class is somewhat pointless. More time should be spent on job and career skills, rather than Buddhist teachings. Neil wants students to know themselves, which may help with careers, so its not THAT bad. Overall, great guy, but I didn't take away too much from this class.
Nice and helpful prof. But the class is a little bit boring and you don't learn a lot.
No Comments
No Comments

he is the nicest proff i have ever had!!!!!!! very easy to talk to very welcoming and he is very understanding.  i would definetly take a future class with him and i highly recommend him to anyone!!!!!!

I took this class by distance education. It was difficult to learn the course objectives and Elive was not a good communication method. Madu forgot about the final exam and did not return assignments until well after the course was finished. Not a class I would recommend by distance education.
Neil is a rare kind of teacher - he actually cares about his students, and will take the time to listen and help you out. Very thoughtful and useful class. Sincere guy.
Interesting man---professionally and personally.  He always cares about his students and is very helpful.  Keep up the good work Neil!
Very interesting lecturer, easy to talk to, helpful.
Wonderful person, made me want to stay at SFU, he actually cares about his students.
The first 3 lectures were cool, then everything he yapped about was the same. The rest of the semester was a waste of time. Boring as hell.
This guy is incredibly unprofessional.  Enough w/ the zen buddhism.  You will not learn anything in his class.
This guy is a great guy and goes the whole mile for students
makes you think

His lectures are so completely off-topic and full of BS that it makes his class irritating. Sure he's easy and all but god is this class a drag. If you get Michelle Funk as your TA, damn shes sexy but she marks so random and difficult and has no valid justification when you confront her. Overall not difficult, just extremely boring.
